conclusion: Liquid will flow out from A, B, and C, and the task is to predict which container (D, E, F, or G) it will flow into after passing through baffles.
Image 1 shows the initial setup with liquid sources A, B, and C at the top, slanted baffles below them, and containers D, E, F, and G at the bottom.
The baffles are positioned to redirect the liquid flow based on their angles.
Image 2 shows liquid flowing from A (white liquid) hitting the light blue baffle, which is slanted downward to the left.
The white liquid from A follows the slope of the blue baffle and flows toward container D.
Image 2 shows liquid flowing from B (green liquid) falling straight down and hitting the red baffle, which is slanted downward to the right.
The green liquid from B follows the slope of the red baffle and flows toward container G.
Image 2 shows liquid flowing from C (pink liquid) falling straight down and hitting the yellow baffle, which is slanted downward to the left.
The pink liquid from C follows the slope of the yellow baffle and flows toward container F.
Image 3 confirms the flow paths: white liquid from A flows into D, green liquid from B flows into G, and pink liquid from C flows into F.
Final confirmation that A flows into D, B flows into G, and C flows into F.
Final answer: A → D, B → G, C → F.
